title: TikTok Owner ByteDance Hires Executive From Xiaomi as CFO
summary: Shou Zi Chew, who ran Xiaomi's finances until 2020, will join ByteDance in Singapore. ByteDance Ltd., owner of the popular TikTok video-sharing platform, has poached an executive from smartphone giant Xiaomi Corp. to become its new finance chief.

title: Former Glencore Oil Trader Pleads Guilty to Manipulating Prices
summary: Trader is cooperating in ongoing investigation into the manipulation, prosecutor said. A former oil trader at mining company Glencore PLC pleaded guilty Wednesday to conspiring to manipulate fuel prices, in a case that signals a new front in a long-running crackdown by prosecutors on efforts to improperly steer oil trading benchmarks that influence real-world prices.

title: Maryland to Pay Four Black Colleges $577 Million
summary: Settlement to redress chronic underfunding. Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan signed a bill Wednesday to pay four historically Black colleges and universities $577 million to settle a 15-year legal battle to address chronic underfunding.

title: Democrats Weigh Increases in Corporate, Personal Income-Tax Rates
summary: President Biden seeks to raise revenue for sweeping infrastructure and education plans. WASHINGTON-Democrats are considering a variety of possible tax increases, including boosting the corporate tax rate and the top marginal income-tax rate on individuals, to raise revenue as President Biden completes his infrastructure, climate and education proposal.

title: Newsom to Name Rob Bonta as California Attorney General
summary: If confirmed, Mr. Bonta would be the first Filipino-American to hold the office. Gavin Newsom will appoint state assemblyman Rob Bonta as California's next attorney general, the governor announced Wednesday.

title: How One of the World's Largest Container Ships Can Get Stuck in the Suez Canal
summary: Resume Subscription. The Ever Given, one of the world's biggest ships, blocked the Suez Canal on Tuesday and Wednesday. The container ship got stuck sideways, causing a backlog of traffic in the busy canal.

title: Slaoui Fired From Startup's Board Over Sexual Harassment Allegations
summary: The former Glaxo executive helped lead the U.S. government's investment in Covid-19 vaccine development. Moncef Slaoui, a veteran pharmaceuticals executive who helped lead the U.S. government's investment in Covid-19 vaccine development, has been fired as chairman of the board of a biotechnology startup backed by GlaxoSmithKline PLC and Google-parent Alphabet Inc. following an investigation into allegations of sexual harassment.

title: Special Dollars for Dictators
summary: Treasury is ducking Congress on $1 trillion in new IMF foreign aid.. More than 250 people have been killed by government security forces in Myanmar since a Feb. 1 military coup. The Biden Administration has imposed sanctions, but then why is the U.S. Treasury moving to hand the Burmese generals a fresh $785 million in foreign aid?

title: Blue-State Voter 'Suppression'
summary: Where's the outcry over Democrats' earlier poll-closing hours and ID rules?. Moves by Republican legislators to reform state election laws are drawing incendiary accusations from Democrats. Former Georgia gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams denounced them as "Jim Crow in a suit and tie." Vice President Kamala Harris declared, "It's all voter suppression by any other name." The Democratic Governors Association calls GOP efforts "a direct attack on our democracy." Such cant is unfounded and damaging to the nation's political culture.

title: Herd Immunity Is Near, Despite Fauci's Denial
summary: His estimate that it'll take a 70% to 85% vaccination rate ignores those who have already been infected.. Anthony Fauci has been saying that the country needs to vaccinate 70% to 85% of the population to reach herd immunity from Covid-19. But he inexplicably ignores natural immunity. If you account for previous infections, herd immunity is likely close at hand.

title: Democrats Use Medicare as a Piggy Bank
summary: Need some money to expand government? Nancy Pelosi knows where to find it.. Speaker Nancy Pelosi's admission that the Biden administration may use drug-pricing legislation to help fund a $3 trillion infrastructure and welfare program may at first glance make little sense: What does one have to do with the other? But Democrats view Medicare less as a solemn commitment to seniors than as a slush fund for new programs.

title: The Coming Demand Surge Brings Back Memories of 1970s Inflation
summary: The lifting of lockdowns and easy monetary and fiscal policy will likely lead to much higher prices.. The last bout of inflation the U.S. experienced was in the 1970s. Commentators duly note this historic reference but don't really understand it-many weren't yet born, and few were adults, at the time. It was no mere inconvenience; it was a catastrophe.

title: Men Looking for Work Drive Surge in Illegal Crossings at the U.S. Border
summary: Resume Subscription. The surge in illegal immigration across the southern U.S. border is shaping up to be the biggest in 20 years. Unlike migrant surges in 2019 and 2014, which were predominantly made up of Central American families and unaccompanied children, so far this one is being driven by individual adults.

title: 50-Cent Words Are No Bargain
summary: Don't say 'recalibrate' when you mean simply 'reconsider.'. Those of us who take an interest in changes in contemporary language are in a condition not unlike that of the village idiot of Frampol, a shtetl in Poland. He was assigned the job of waiting at the gates for the Messiah and was told: The pay is low but the work is steady.

title: 'Paper Trails' Review: Go West, Young Mailman
summary: If rumors of riches triggered a stampede to a mining camp, the Post Ofﬁce Department was expected to serve the location right away.. For most of us who call ourselves historians, our work is first and foremost a matter of writing. Our offices teem with books. Our journals feature lengthy articles. We don't shy away from maps, charts, photographs and drawings, but their purpose, more often than not, is to illustrate-literally, to shed light upon-information conveyed by written words.

title: Notable & Quotable: Ben Sasse on Filibuster Flip-Flops
summary: 'I don't remember Senator Schatz then calling it the Jim Crow filibuster when he wrote that letter, or when he was blocking Tim Scott's police reform legislation last year.'. Sen. Ben Sasse (R., Neb.) in a March 23 floor speech:

title: Slack Backtracks on New Way to Message Over Harassment Concern
summary: Workplace chat pioneer says it made a mistake in how it rolled out direct-messaging function. Slack Technologies Inc. launched a new push to expand the utility of its widely used collaboration app only to backtrack hours later amid concern it could inadvertently facilitate harassment.

title: Bernie Sanders's Censorship Wisdom
summary: He knows Big Tech's speech muzzling won't only be used against the right.. Democrats have increasingly adopted Bernie Sanders's ideas about economic policy. If only they'd instead take the Vermont socialist seriously on speech and censorship.

title: Why Do Democrats Hate West Virginia?
summary: First they attack energy production. Then they block a state tax cut.. West Virginia has lost population for eight consecutive years. Gov. Jim Justice is pushing to phase out his state's income tax to make it more economically competitive, but Democrats are sabotaging him with their $1.9 trillion spending bill.

title: News Flash: It's a Bad Bill, H.R.1
summary: The proposed law is finally getting some critical scrutiny.. The Democratic narrative behind H.R.1, an 800-page House bill that would (among other things) federalize election administration, has been mostly cheered on by the press. But there now are, at last, signs of a dawning realization that this is not good legislation.

title: New York City to Invest $300 Million in Preschool for 3-Year-Olds
summary: Mayor De Blasio cites need for child care and better outcomes for children who go to preschool as basis for expansion. New York City will expand its preschool program in September, creating a universal program that will be open to all age-eligible children across the city, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Wednesday.

title: Stocks End Lower Amid Decline in Tech Shares
summary: Nasdaq falls 2% as investors take in more testimony from Powell and Yellen. U.S. stocks closed lower Wednesday as investors continued to pull back from the technology stocks that led the market higher for much of the last year.

title: H&M Criticized in China Over Xinjiang Forced-Labor Stance
summary: State media, social-media users and celebrity endorsers lambast fast-fashion company-with some calling for a boycott-over months-old statement. HONG KONG-The world's largest clothing brand, Hennes & Mauritz AB's H&M , is under assault in China, one of its biggest markets, over its stance on forced labor in the country's remote cotton-producing region of Xinjiang.

title: Supreme Court Considers Police Leeway Without Warrant
summary: Justices hear arguments in case seeking to draw line between police's law-enforcement and care-taking functions. WASHINGTON-At Supreme Court arguments Wednesday, the justices considered the constitutional constraints when police enter a home not to investigate crime, but to protect health, safety or property.

title: Dubai Fair Offers First Test of Covid-Era Art Market
summary: The U.A.E. is hoping to attract high-end tourists with a live cultural event while the art world watches to see who shows up. Dubai

title: Top Colleges in the Northeast for Diversity
summary: Rutgers University-Newark and the University of Massachusetts Boston head this list in the WSJ/THE College Rankings. Rutgers University-Newark and the University of Massachusetts Boston are the highest-ranked schools for diversity in the Northeast in the Wall Street Journal/Times Higher Education College rankings. The two schools are tied at No. 5 nationally in this category.

title: NYPD Creates Online Portal for Filing Some Criminal Complaints
summary: New web tool allows residents to submit reports for low-level crimes, including petit larceny and graffiti. New York Police Department officials are encouraging members of the public to report some low-level crimes to the department using a new online tool that the officials announced Wednesday.

title: After Anti-Asian Violence, Volunteers Take to Streets to Form Patrols
summary: Resume Subscription. FLUSHING, N.Y.-Before sunset Monday, a few dozen Asian-Americans outfitted in neon vests and jackets combed the streets of this New York City neighborhood.

title: Verizon's Quest for 5G Revenue
summary: The company's strategy chief hunts for new ways to monetize the service after big spend on spectrum. As Verizon Communications Inc. rolls out 5G service, Rima Qureshi has a clear mission: find ways to move beyond providing basic connectivity.

title: A Commercial Real-Estate Investor Pivots to Digital-Related Assets
summary: Colony Capital sells its warehouses and hotels and puts its money in cell towers, data centers and other digital infrastructure. Colony Capital Inc. has made one of the biggest pivots in the real-estate business. Over the past two years, the former investor in commercial real estate has sold warehouses, hotels and other traditional properties and plowed the proceeds into data centers, cell towers and fiber-network assets.

title: Biden and the Trillions
summary: Democrats hope he'll emulate the man who created the last great inflation.. Since last March politicians have somehow managed to get away with shutting down heavily indebted economies and then borrowing and printing money as a substitute. Now many are determined to ignore nearly all of human history prior to 2008 and conclude that there really are no limits to the ability of a government treasury to issue debt, much of which is later purchased by another arm of government with money created out of thin air.

title: Hot U.S. Economy, Supply Disruptions Pressure World's Factories
summary: The strongest U.S. expansion in 30 years is making for long delivery delays and price increases, exacerbated by Suez disruption, factory fires. Resurgent economies, led by the U.S., and a burst of demand for consumer goods are heaping pressure on already strained supply chains, with a series of acute disruptions-including this week's blockage of the Suez Canal-set to worsen shortages and further push up prices.

title: KFC, Taco Bell to Start Taking Orders via Text
summary: Parent Yum Brands acquires Israeli startup that developed the software after testing technology in 900 restaurants. KFC-owner Yum Brands Inc. is buying an Israeli-based startup that helps customers order food to go via text, a strategy executives hope will fuel sales as people shift away from fast food and return to full-service restaurants.

title: Not Into a Bikini? Try Katharine Hepburn's Layered Summer Style
summary: No one was as adept at the art of wearing multiple shirts as Ms. Hepburn, especially in 'On Golden Pond' in 1981. I WOULDN'T say that the '80s movie "On Golden Pond," starring Henry Fonda and Katharine Hepburn as a patrician, graying couple, has aged particularly well. Its sentimental depiction of lakeside living, its sepia-crusted cinematography and its Muzak score feel like relics of a different time. But what doesn't feel like a relic is the wardrobe Ms. Hepburn wears to portray the nearly-70-year-old Ethel Thayer. In almost every scene, she offers some version of one distinctive look: a turtleneck layered under a button-up shirt.

title: Flying in Formation (Thursday Crossword, March 25)
Debt Investors Await More Details on Biden's Infrastructure Plan
summary: Yields have paused in recent sessions even after reports that Biden administration officials are crafting a plan for a multipart infrastructure and economic package that could cost as much as $3 trillion. Bond investors are taking a wait-and-see approach to President Biden's next major spending push.

title: GameStop's Reality Should Take a Bigger Bite
summary: Despite postearnings selloff, videogame retailer's market value still banks on a massive turnaround success. One can appreciate the dilemma facing GameStop 's management: What could they possibly say that would be worth $11.5 billion?

title: Boulder Shooting Spurs Calls for Gun Control in Colorado
summary: Suspect purchased his semiautomatic weapon outside of Boulder, where a judge blocked a ban on such firearms. Colorado lawmakers are calling for tougher restrictions on guns as investigators continue to search for clues about why a 21-year-old gunman killed 10 people at a Boulder supermarket on Monday.

title: Tencent Stresses Regulatory Compliance as Profits Surge
summary: Gaming giant benefited from a pandemic lockdown last year but faces scrutiny from Chinese regulators. TAIPEI- Tencent Holdings Ltd. Chief Executive Pony Ma emphasized his commitment to working with regulators amid heightened government scrutiny over China's powerful technology companies, as strong growth in mobile gaming and payments propelled the social-media and entertainment giant to its most profitable year yet.

title: EU, U.K. Seek to End Vaccine Fight as Bloc Broadens Export Controls
summary: European Union leaders will discuss export ban system in talks Thursday. The U.K. and European Union said they were working on steps to defuse a fight over vaccine supplies after the EU set out a plan that would make it easier for the bloc's governments to block Covid-19 vaccine exports.

title: Westpac New Zealand Unit Ordered to Review Risk Management
summary: Westpac Banking Corp. said it is considering a demerger of the unit. SYDNEY- Westpac Banking Corp. said it is considering a sale or spinoff of its New Zealand business after regulators there ordered it to review its risk management.

title: Leap in Gas Prices Puts $3 a Gallon in Sight
summary: Analysts expect crowded highways and diminished stockpiles to lift gas prices into the summer driving season. The prospect of summer drivers crowding U.S. highways is powering steep gains in the price of gasoline, a sign of economic recovery and a boon for the pandemic-ravaged energy industry.

title: What to Watch: 16 Movies and TV Series to Stream This Week
summary: 'Senior Moment' is a rom-com starring 90-year-old William Shatner; plus 'Invincible' grapples with the collateral damage wrought by superheroes. More and more theaters are opening as audiences get more comfortable stepping outside their homes. For those who are decidedly stayin' in, there is, of course, still plenty to watch. Here's what's new in the worlds of William Shatner, "The Mighty Ducks," Sherlock Holmes and more:

title: Greensill Leaned on Wall Street Before It Collapsed
summary: Citigroup expanded its business with Greensill despite repeated warnings internally not to do so. LONDON-The founder of Greensill Capital spoke frequently about disrupting big banks. But before the financial startup collapsed this month, it relied on the apparatus of Wall Street to fuel its expansion.

title: Why Fossil Hunting Is the Next Big Hobby-Seriously
summary: Searching out ammonites and ancient shark teeth is fast becoming an alternative outdoorsy hobby with bragging rights. Here, a guide to the surprisingly chic tools and brainy apps that will elevate your treasure hunt.. INDIANA JONES was no mere grubby excavator. An esteemed professor, he was also a looker who wore fedoras with élan. Among Americans looking to expend pent-up wanderlust and perhaps brag a little, the paleontological pastime of fossil hunting has become an increasingly popular Jonesian pursuit. Tim Jones (no relation), the community administrator of the Fossil Forum, which has 1.2 million posted messages, says he's amazed by what new converts have found in their 'hoods and along river banks. Still, you're thinking, "Mud? Seems like fedoras won't figure highly in my new hobby." Maybe not, but here's a guide to surprisingly chic tools and brainy apps that elevate the hunt.

title: Merck Names 30-Year Company Veteran as CFO
summary: Caroline Litchfield is set to take over the pharmaceutical giant's finances on April 1. Drugmaker Merck & Co. promoted a 30-year company veteran to the role of finance chief after elevating the incumbent to chief executive officer.

title: Dan Snyder Buys Out Washington Football Team's Minority Owners
summary: Snyder has agreed to buy the shares from his team's limited partners after an ugly dispute inside the billion-dollar NFL team that turned public. Washington Football Team majority owner Dan Snyder has agreed to buy the shares owned by the team's limited partners, a league spokesman said, bringing an end to a boardroom brawl inside an NFL franchise that has been mired in controversy on numerous fronts.

title: PG&E Elevates Interim Finance Chief to Permanent Role
summary: The utility is working to strengthen its business after emerging from bankruptcy. PG&E Corp. promoted its interim finance chief to the permanent role as the utility works to stabilize the business after the company's equipment sparked a series of deadly wildfires, forcing it into bankruptcy.

title: Facebook Takes Down China-Linked Hacking Campaign Targeting Uyghurs
summary: The effort included setting up fake news sites and compromising real ones to infect people's devices. Facebook Inc. has taken down a network of China-based accounts being used to spread malware meant to spy on journalists and dissidents in the overseas Uyghur Muslim community, the company said on Wednesday.

title: Texas Energy Regulators Can't Dodge Blame
summary: When government doesn't regulate, our very competitive industry cuts costs to the bone.. Can gaslighting be powered by natural gas? Or plain, old hot air? Yes and yes, as illustrated in Wayne Christian's "Texas' Blackouts Blew In on the Wind" (Cross Country, March 20), which skillfully redirects blame from the culprit and assigns it to a popular scapegoat.

title: Pandemic Shows How Fast Medicine Can Move
summary: We should never return to the boom-and-bust cycles that funded research only when a crisis arises.. Eric Topol's "The Hyper-Acceleration of the Life Sciences" (Review, March 20) correctly celebrates the medical research community's Covid vaccine and treatment successes. One key was private industry-government partnerships. Traditional competitors also collaborated to compress time and regulators allowed overlapping safety/efficacy reviews, two strategies we began advocating decades ago.

title: Biden Moving Slowly in Filling Key National-Security Posts
summary: Out of 300 jobs, administration has named 16 picks thus far as Biden critics, supporters cite range of reasons for pace of nominations. WASHINGTON-President Biden has yet to name hundreds of administration officials requiring Senate confirmation to military, diplomatic and intelligence posts, making it unlikely that his security agencies will be fully staffed until fall, officials say.

title: A GPS Outage Would Leave the World Lost
summary: Interagency squabbling and penny-wise budget decisions over the years have left the country exposed.. Diana Furchtgott-Roth asks rhetorically, "Will We Be Ready if GPS Goes Down?" (op-ed, March 20). Today, despite an increase in the frequency of GPS outages (some intentional), the answer is no. That's why her urgent plea for funding backup technology, in keeping with the Transportation Department's recent report to Congress, deserves prompt attention. DOT has been serving up sound, peer-reviewed recommendations since the George W. Bush administration. Yet interagency squabbling and penny-wise budget decisions over the years have left the country exposed to the consequences of a GPS failure.

title: Suez Canal, Source of Pride and Conflict, Regains Spotlight
summary: Resume Subscription. CAIRO-A massive cargo ship stuck in Egypt's Suez Canal has cast a spotlight on the 150 year-old waterway that remains one of the world's most important arteries for trade, a symbol of Egyptian pride and a historic source of friction among foreign powers.

title: 'For Real: The Story of Reality TV' Review: Keeping Up With Pop Culture
summary: Andy Cohen hosts and produces a series that attempts to take a critical look at the 'Real Housewives' and 'Kardashians' universe of shows. The thrust of "For Real: The Story of Reality TV" is that there is reality television, and then there's real reality television. Kardashians. "Kendra on Top." Danny Bonaduce. "Dance Moms." The genre, such as it is, is not about news, documentaries or even hybrids like "To Catch a Predator." It's about the stuff that profoundly, rigorously and even exhaustively doesn't matter. Except in the arena of self-promotion. And then it's epic.

title: New York Lawmakers Reach Deal to Legalize Marijuana
summary: After years of impasse, New York is poised to become the 15th state in the country to allow the recreational use of the drug. ALBANY, N.Y.-After years of false starts, New York state lawmakers said Wednesday that they had reached an agreement to legalize the sale of marijuana for recreational use by adults starting next year.

title: Facebook's Zuckerberg Proposes Raising Bar for Section 230
summary: Congress should consider requiring internet platforms to earn liability immunity, CEO says ahead of Thursday hearing. WASHINGTON- Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg said Congress should consider forcing digital platforms to earn the legal immunity they enjoy hosting third-party content, a legal change that could affect a range of online businesses.

title: Meet the Man Who Sets Up 5G Networks
summary: Toussant Won Jr.'s job is to make sure private 5G networks at stadiums, warehouses and factories are up to speed. Toussant Won Jr. relies on two very different tools to help corporate customers plan, install and operate 5G networks: one state-of-the-art, the other old-fashioned.

title: Powell Says Rise in Bond Yields Reflects Optimism About Economy
summary: Fed chairman, in Senate testimony with Treasury Secretary Yellen, said increase in 10-year Treasury yield has been 'an orderly process'. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell indicated Wednesday that he isn't concerned about a recent rise in long-term bond yields, saying they appear to reflect growing optimism about the economy's prospects.

title: Mormon Church Accused of Financial Fraud in Lawsuit
summary: James Huntsman alleges that the church misrepresented how money he and other members donated would be used. The brother of a former Utah governor sued the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints this week, alleging that the church defrauded its members and misused donations known as tithing.

title: $300 for Hiking Shoes? Why Outdoorsy Types Are Splurging
summary: Brands like New Balance and Roa are pushing handsome, pricey sneaker-boots purported to perform as well on the mountain trail as on the sidewalk. But are they worth the investment?. SOMEWHERE IN the liminal space between beefy hiking boots and look-at-me sneakers, you will find Roa's trail shoes. The 6-year-old Italian label produces fetching footwear that shouts high design more than it does high altitude. Mesh panels add shimmer to sneakers while the sides of an ankle-high boot sport curious green "grass" splotches. But the designs also incorporate trail-conquering tech like tractiony Vibram soles and water-repellent nylon. Ringing in at about $250 and up, Roa's hoity hybrid hikers don't come cheap.

title: U.S. Covid-19 Supercomputing Group Evaluates Year-Long Effort
summary: The group, which includes Microsoft, IBM and U.S. national labs, helped researchers world-wide gain access to 600 petaflops of computing capacity. Researchers working on nearly 100 projects related to Covid-19 around the globe have had free access to some of the world's most powerful computers in the past year, courtesy of a consortium led in part by the U.S. government and technology companies.

title: Juliet Balconies Add Drama Without the Tragedy
summary: Resume Subscription. When Juliet rhapsodizes, "O Romeo, Romeo! Wherefore art thou Romeo?" Shakespeare wrote that she stood at a window. Subsequent performances, though, depicted Juliet standing on a balconette and that romantic association led to the feature being forever known as the Juliet balcony.

title: Israel's Election Impasse Threatens the Country's Covid-19 Recovery

title: After Year of Covid-19, New York Doctor Finds 'Lightness of Spirit' in Vaccination Role
summary: Resume Subscription. A year ago this week, hospitals in New York City were already feeling the surge of patients with Covid-19 and Dr. Daniela Diaz was on her second pivot of the pandemic.

title: How to Restore Balance to Libel Law
summary: The Supreme Court can curtail the worst media abuse without overturning its landmark 1964 ruling.. If a news organization defames you, it's almost impossible to find redress in an American court. In 1964 the Supreme Court began to remake libel law in New York Times Co. v. Sullivan. The changes made it harder for victims of defamation to sue media outlets that defamed them, adding a requirement of "actual malice" for public officials seeking to recover damages.

title: New York Needs to Release Its Covid Data
summary: The only way to regain the people's trust is to let them see the state's information on every test, infection, hospitalization and death.. Albany has kept New Yorkers in the dark for months about Covid-related deaths in nursing homes, and someone finally needs to pull back the curtain and let the sun shine in. The necessary reckoning should start with a bold exercise in transparent government: The state Health Department should open its vault of pandemic data and release every last digit to the public. No Freedom of Information requests. No lawsuits. No subpoenas. Give public information to the public.

title: February's Economic Setback Won't Prove Durable
summary: A range of economic data show the economy suffered a setback in February, but conditions already appear to be improving. Another day, another report showing the economy weakened last month.

title: Cell-Tower Climber Makes 5G Infrastructure Ready for Prime Time
summary: An engineer and a climber, Kelsey Olson prepares sky-high structures to support the next generation of wireless equipment. The job interview that got Kelsey Olson's foot in the door to the cellular-tower industry began with a straightforward question.

title: The Cathartic Technology of Greek Tragedy
summary: Ancient playwrights knew things about overcoming trauma that modern psychology is only beginning to discover.. What if literature contains a secret technology for maximizing our mental health and happiness? Such was the brave hypothesis sketched with sticky pine ink upon a Nile grass scroll in 335 BCE. The sketcher was Aristotle, whose chase to explain daydreams and why-do-I-thrill-at-the-rainbow had inspired him, a decade or so prior, to venture into amateur psychology. And the scroll was the Poetics, the world's earliest surviving stab at literary criticism.

title: Ship Stuck in Suez Canal Heightens Pressure on Global Supply Chain
summary: Even brief disruption of the vital passage for oil and gas and global trade in clothing and electronics could have significant impact. The blockage of the Suez Canal by a grounded container ship will likely add delays and extra costs to an already pressured logistics industry, say executives, punctuating the tightness of the world's supply lines.

title: The Best Printers for the Home-Say Goodbye to Ink Cartridges
summary: Stop buying cheap inkjet printers, then paying a fortune for cartridges. Instead, get an ink-tank or a laser printer, our columnist says, after testing 10 home printers. Once upon a time, there was a tech columnist who bought a $150 printer with a model number so long it's now her bank password.

title: Canadian Housing Boom Raises Concern, With Homes Selling Far Above Prices Asked
summary: Dramatic pandemic run-up leads G-7 countries and spawns worries about real estate's outsize role. OTTAWA-The U.S. may be experiencing its biggest housing boom in decades, but one country has been outpacing its peers in home-price growth: Canada.

title: Move Over Huawei, Xiaomi Is China's New Smartphone King
summary: Gadget maker's global fortunes revive as tech giant stumbles under a string of blows from the U.S.. HONG KONG-The swift decline in Huawei Technologies Co.'s smartphone business under the weight of U.S. sanctions has left an opening in the market. summary: The newly built, 10,200-square-foot estate also includes an elliptical staircase, waterfalls and a 92-foot-long infinity pool. In Beverly Hills, a newly built house with four kitchens and an elliptical staircase is listing for $33.95 million.

title: A 'Modern Art Deco' Mansion in Beverly Hills

title: Young ETF Buyers Discover the Tech Sector's Old Friend, the QQQ
summary: The mysterious ticker name and branding of the ETF have helped to attract fractional and beginner investors. Everything old is new again in the markets, even popular exchange-traded funds.

title: How a Covid-19 Vaccine That Caught Trump's Eye Lost Its Way-and Found It Back
summary: CureVac founder tells of surprise illness and efforts to bring the company back on track. BERLIN-Early last year, Ingmar Hörr was at the forefront of the world's race to make the first Covid-19 vaccine. The company he had founded and was leading, CureVac NV, had developed a promising candidate using largely untested technology he pioneered.

title: At 55, a Debut Author Finds Stardom With the Novel She First Dreamed Up at 18
summary: First, the author got a seven-figure deal; then her novel was optioned by the Obamas and chosen for Reese Witherspoon's book club. Last century: Angeline Boulley was a young mother of three.

title: 2021's Most Coveted Flowers? Pale Dahlias for the Garden
summary: Traditionally, big, showy dahlias come in potent colors. What's trending now, however, are sophisticated pastels-quieter but no less magnificent. Here, our 5 top picks.. DAHLIAS HAVE ALWAYS conferred magnificence to the late-summer garden. The blooms are enormous-"dinner plate" dahlias span 10 inches. Traditionally, their colors are equally unmousey: bottomless purples, regal fuchsias and velvety reds. But lately, dahlia worshipers are giving priority to softer shades of splendor. Creamy, understated pastels are in. "I think it has something to do with wedding trends," said Erin Benzakein, founder of Floret farm, in Mount Vernon, Wash., and author of the new book "Discovering Dahlias" (Chronicle Books). "Blush, champagne, buttercream-those colors have become really popular in the last couple of years, and there's extra frenzy to find varieties in that palette."

title: U.S. Durable-Goods Orders Drop for First Time Since Last Spring
summary: New orders declined 1.1% in February as factories struggle to get parts. Orders for long-lasting manufactured goods fell in February as U.S. factories faced supply-chain challenges.

title: Texas Roadhouse CEO, a Business Maverick, Was Tormented by Tinnitus After Covid-19
summary: The steakhouse founder, who has died at 65, struggled with crippling ringing in his ears. After coming down with a mild case of Covid-19 in November, W. Kent Taylor found himself tormented by tinnitus, a ringing in the ears. It persisted and grew so distracting that the founder and chief executive of the restaurant chain Texas Roadhouse Inc. had trouble reading or concentrating.

title: Books to Read: The Best Reviews of March
summary: 'The Committed,' 'A Beginner's Guide to America,' 'When Brains Dream' and more of the most fascinating reads of the month..

title: Carbon Tax Sidelined in Biden's Push on Climate, Taxes
summary: President, some Democrats fret over inequities from pricing carbon, despite lack of evidence. There is no more effective way for President Biden to meet his aggressive climate goals than a carbon tax. The timing seems ripe: his Treasury Secretary, Janet Yellen, has been a prominent advocate. Big business has flipped from opponent to proponent. Republican opposition is no longer monolithic.

title: GameStop, Intel, Tesla: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Futures suggested that technology shares would lead gains at the open. Here's what we're watching ahead of Wednesday's opening bell.

title: The Best Wines and Gear for Drinking Outside
summary: Uncorking in the open air shouldn't mean settling for lesser bottles or insects in your glass. Here's how to get maximum pleasure from imbibing en plein air.. ONCE UPON A TIME, in pre-pandemic days, drinking wine outside with friends was a choice and not a necessity. But like most oenophiles, I learned to adjust as the weeks of privation stretched into months. I drank wine on patios in the summer and next to heaters and firepits in the fall. In the winter I didn't drink wine outside at all. But now that spring has finally arrived, I'm looking forward to spending more time imbibing outdoors.

title: Your Hair Is Also Experiencing Pandemic-Related Stress. Here's What to Do.
summary: Just like skin, hair shows the impact of stress, lack of sleep and the passage of time. Brands addressing hair aging are taking a holistic approach, one that starts at the root.. In January of last year the actor Ricki Lake posted a selfie with a buzz cut. In the caption she revealed that she had been suffering from hair loss for nearly 30 years. "Ever since I played Tracy Turnblad in the original Hairspray back in 1988 and they triple-processed and teased my then healthy virgin hair every 2 weeks during filming, my hair was never the same," Lake wrote. She'd gone "from Hairspray to hairless." The response to her confession, which reached an even larger audience when she appeared soon after on Good Morning America, revealed just how many women related to her struggle.

title: Hong Kong Bank Reaches Insurance Deal After Pressure from Elliott Management
summary: Bank of East Asia to sell its insurance business to pan-Asian life insurer AIA Group. HONG KONG- Bank of East Asia Ltd. agreed to sell its insurance business to pan-Asian life insurer AIA Group Ltd., marking a milestone in one of the longest-running shareholder activism campaigns in the region.

title: Retailers and Landlords Clash Over What Counts as a Sale
summary: Rents based on percentage of sales leave room for interpretation as line between online and store sales blurs. Stores are reopening and customers are streaming back in, which means retailers that withheld rent during Covid-19 shutdowns are now able to pay. But first they have to agree with their landlords on how to define a sale.

title: Baseball's Oldest Living Player Heads Back to the Ballpark
summary: Eddie Robinson celebrated his 100th birthday and went to spring training. He also hosts a podcast.. For Eddie Robinson, 2020 marked the end of an almost unimaginable streak: He didn't attend a Major League Baseball game for the first time since 1945, thanks to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Don't Buy the Wrong Volkswagen
summary: Mixture of indiscriminate share buying and hedge-fund short covering has driven a wedge between virtually identical Volkswagen securities. If you find two almost identical Volkswagens on a dealer lot and one costs 25% less than the other, it should be obvious that you are better off buying the cheaper one. A surprising number of investors seem to be forgetting that the same logic applies to the stock market.

title: Road Is Smoother Than Expected for Infrastructure, Biden Plan or Not
summary: Traffic and revenue sources for transportation haven't dried up as much as states expected last year. Infrastructure bills have promised big and delivered little in the past. Will it be different this time around?

title: Covid-19 Relief Could Stimulate Fintech Stocks
summary: Some high-flying digital banking and fintech stocks such as Square and PayPal have cooled a bit this year, but stimulus checks going out might bump up results later this year. Millions of Americans have started getting another round of stimulus-and so, by extension, could many fintech companies.

title: Digital Designers Take Professional Collaboration Tools and Riff on Them
summary: Figma, a prototyping platform, is being turned toward off-label pursuits, among them off-sites for team-building, fan art, interior design, even wedding-planning. Bonnie Kate Wolf once spent 12 hours on Figma creating fan art of Taylor Swift.

title: Cardinal Health, FourKites Target Deeper View of Medical Supply Chain
summary: FourKites lands $100 million in a new funding round as tracking technology takes on new urgency in distributing medical equipment, vaccines. When Covid-19 infections surged in New York last spring, a rush on medical supplies caught healthcare providers off guard, challenging inventory and tracking systems built for more predictable demand.

title: World Skating Championships Open With Skaters on Edge
summary: Top figure skaters have their first major matchup in two years, with Olympic spots-and Covid-19-on their minds. It's been two years since the world's top figure skaters all last went head-to-head. The next time they do it, it will be at the 2022 Winter Olympic Games.

title: HSBC Searches for China's Wealthy With an Army of Roaming Bankers
summary: Pinnacle is critical to CEO Noel Quinn's plan to revive the bank's lagging fortunes. HSBC Holdings PLC has a new plan to find riches in China. It is hiring 3,000 branchless bankers to search prosperous coastal cities for wealthy clients who need advice on insurance and investments.

title: Quick to Contain Covid-19, Asia Trails West in Vaccinations
summary: Mainland China and Hong Kong have covered around 5% of their populations; most Asian countries are at less than 3%. Vaccine rollouts around the world have upended the narrative of the pandemic's first year, as the Asian countries that succeeded in containing Covid-19 have now fallen behind much of the West in the race toward herd immunity.

title: Federal Reserve's Bostic Expects Central Bank Will Lift Rates in 2023
summary: Atlanta Fed chief also expects a 'fair amount of time' before the central bank pares asset purchases. Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic is penciling in 2023 as the year the U.S. central bank will be able to start lifting its near zero short-term interest rate target range.

title: Auto Dealerships Can't Keep Up With New Models. The Global Chip Shortage Is to Blame.
summary: Car industry entered 2021 hoping to restock, but supply-chain problems are extending the crunch-meaning slimmer pickings, higher prices and longer waits. Utah dealer Stephen Wade is running out of pickup trucks-and fast.

title: Blockchain.com Raises $300 Million
summary: The investment round gave the company a $5.2 billion valuation. Blockchain.com, a London-based firm that provides a variety of cryptocurrency services to retail and institutional clients, raised $300 million in a deal that highlights venture capital's growing willingness to jump back into the bitcoin frenzy.

title: Slow-Vaccinating Asia Is Squandering Its Economic Advantages
summary: Countries that suppressed or eliminated Covid-19 outbreaks lag in vaccinating, delaying a full recovery. As late as last autumn, suggesting that countries where Covid-19 outbreaks had been suppressed or controlled would suffer a longer-lasting shortfall in consumer demand than the U.S. would have seemed fanciful. It no longer does.

title: North Korea Fires First Missiles During Biden Presidency
summary: U.S. says Kim regime launched short-range missiles, protesting joint American-South Korean military exercises. North Korea launched several short-range missiles over the weekend, U.S. and South Korean officials said, in a show of defiance against President Biden and his administration that was widely expected after joint U.S.-South Korea military exercises.

title: Two Democrats Back Off Threat to Block Some Biden Picks in Push for More Asian-Americans
summary: Sens. Tammy Duckworth and Mazie Hirono raised concerns over the lack of representation in the executive branch of Asian-Americans and Pacific Islanders. WASHINGTON-The White House said late Tuesday that it will add to its staff a senior-level liaison to represent Asian-Americans and Pacific Islanders, satisfying two Democratic senators who had threatened to withhold votes for top administration nominees over diversity concerns.

title: Boulder Shooting Suspect Charged With 10 Counts of Murder
summary: Police name local 21-year-old as suspect; 10 victims in mass shooting range from age 20 to 65. BOULDER, Colo.-Monday afternoon was quiet at the King Soopers grocery store on Table Mesa Drive. A smattering of shoppers meandered through the aisles. Several waited for Covid-19 vaccinations at the pharmacy. At the Starbucks , Logan Smith brewed a coffee for his friend and co-worker Denny Stong.

title: Brazil Court Ruling Paves Way for Lula da Silva Presidential Bid
summary: The ex-president's 2017 bribery conviction is thrown out after Supreme Court rules judge in that case was biased. SÃO PAULO-Brazil's Supreme Court ruled that the judge who convicted former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of corruption was biased, strengthening the leftist leader's likely election bid next year.

title: New York Nursing-Home Fire Kills One, Leaves One Missing
summary: Gov. Cuomo directed state police to aid in probe of blaze at Evergreen Court Home for Adults in Rockland County. New York state and local police are investigating a fire in a nursing home in a New York City suburb that left at least one resident dead and a firefighter missing, officials said Tuesday.

title: Adobe CFO John Murphy to Retire
summary: The software maker reported higher profit and revenue for the latest quarter, and raised its projections for the year. Software maker Adobe Inc. is searching for a new finance chief as incumbent Chief Financial Officer John Murphy plans to retire.

title: Online-Gaming Platform Rec Room Valued at $1.25 Billion in Fundraising Round
summary: Revenue has surged during the pandemic for the company, which lets users play in customized game worlds. Rec Room Inc., a videogame platform that enables users to build and play in customized online spaces, garnered a $1.25 billion valuation in its latest funding round as the company benefits from a surging number of users during the coronavirus pandemic.
